australian.text: Those who lose dreaming are lost.
Don’t count your chickens before they’re hatched.
A bad worker blames his tools.
A miles journey starts with a single step.
Keep your eyes on the sun and you will not see the shadows.
May as well be here we are as where we are.
The more you know, the less you need.
Those who lost dreaming are lost.
One man's meat is another man's poison.
Our purpose here is to observe, to learn, to grow, to love; and then we return home.
The clash of ideas brings forth the spark of truth.
We are all visitors to this time, this place. We are just passing through.
You might as well be hanged for a sheep as for a lamb.
A bad worker blames his tools.
A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Blood is thicker than water.
Don't blow your own trumpet.
Don't count your chickens before they're hatched.
God helps those who help themselves.
Half a loaf is better than none.
The frog does not tire in the water.
In the planting season visitors come singly, and in harvest time they come in crowds.
Give cheerfully with one hand and you will gather well with two.
None so deaf as those who would not hear.
Once bitten, twice shy.
Those who play at bowls must look out for rubbers.
Those who play bowls must look out for rubbers.
We are all visitors to this time, this place. We are just passing through. Our purpose here is to observe, to learn, to grow, to love... and then we return home.
None are so deaf as those who would not hear.
In the planting season, visitors come singly, and in harvest time they come in crowds.
A bad workman blames his tools.
A bird makes his nest little by little.
A champion team will always beat a team of champions.
A determined soul will do more with a rusty monkey wrench than a loafer will accomplish with all the tools in a machine shop.
A fair go for all, regardless of ethnicity, race, religion, except for Poms, Seppos and Kiwis.
A good conscience is a soft pillow.
A handsome shoe often pinches the foot.
A man is known by his friends.
A man may be a tough, concentrated, successful money-maker and never contribute to his country anything more than a horrible example.
A Man of Business is one who becomes possessed of other people’s money, without bringing himself under the power of the law.
A Platypus is a duck designed by a committee.
A spark can start a great fire.
A stitch in time saves nine.
A truly happy person is one who can enjoy the scenery on a detour.
A watched pot never boils.
A wise man doesn’t need advice, and a fool won’t take it.
A wowser is…a person who is more shocked at seeing two inches of underskirt than a mountain of misery.
A wowser…is a man who, being entirely destitute of the greater virtues, makes up for their lack by a continuous denunciation of little vices.
Actions speak louder than words.
australian.description: The Greek philosopher Plato once said that action is character. People are not defined by what they say because a lot of talk does not mean anything. People are judged by the things they do. Your actions are more important than what you say.

australian.text: After the storm comes the calm.
All our best heroes are losers.

All the evil in his nature (and who is without any) had been developed and nourished by harsh and cruel treatment, kindling, perhaps, a revengeful feeling against all mankind – a feeling, often the cause, in Australia at a future period, of the barbarous murder of innocent individuals.
Always back the horse named self-interest, son. It’ll be the only one trying.
Angry words fan the fire like wind.
As a leader you must celebrate life, you must celebrate success and paradoxically, you must celebrate heroic failures.
As a work of art, it reminds me of a long conversation between two drunks.
As is the gardener so is the garden.
Australia – land of tomorrow.
Australia is a nation of compassion. Courage and compassion. And the third of these great values: resilience.
Australia is just so full of surprises.

Australia lives with a strange contradiction – our national image of ourselves is one of the Outback, and yet nearly all us live in big cities. Move outside the coastal fringe, and Australia can feel like a foreign country.
Australian seafarers make an important contribution to national security in a country with thousands of kilometres of uninhabited coastline.
Australians always want everyone to be average, as if the best thing you can do is fit in.
Australians and the British are very similar: If you try and stand out in any way, and you try to reach for success, someone is gonna be there to cut you down.
Australians are a passionate lot. We are also a very practical lot.
Australians are very provincial in many ways. If they feel that you’ve used them as a stepping stone to bigger things, they resent it.
Australians will never acquire a national identity until individual Australians acquire identities of their own.
Australia’s treatment of her Aboriginal people will be the thing on which the world will judge Australia and Australians – Not just now, but in the greater perspective of history.
Bad news travels fast.
Before you criticise someone, you should walk a mile in their shoes. That way, when you criticise them, you’re a mile away and have their shoes.
Being an Australian that’s been No. 1 in the world back home playing in Australia, that’s a pretty cool moment to have.
Being different is easy. Doing something better than others is hard.
Better safe than sorry.
Better to have than to wish.
Big fish eat little fish.
By 1990, no Australian child will be living in poverty.
Call a spade a spade.
Call on God, but row away from the rocks.
Charity begins at home.
Crying is for poofters and girls.
Cut your coat according to the cloth.
Distance lends enhancement to the view.
Distance makes the heart grow fonder.
Do right and fear no man.
Do you know why I have credibility? Because I don’t exude morality.
Dog must not steal from dog.
Don’t blow your own trumpet.
Don’t count your chickens before they are hatched.
australian.description: This proverb warns against being too eager. Just because you have five eggs, does not mean you will have five chickens. It is not a good idea to make plans based on expectations (what you think will happen). Wait for all things to come true before building up your dreams. Or worse, your promises. Things may not happen like you thought they would and that could get you in trouble.

australian.text: Don’t look a gift horse in the mouth.
Empty vessels make the most sound.

Encourage your people to be committed to a project rather than just involved in it. You know the difference between involvement and commitment don’t you? In a meal of bacon and eggs, the chicken is involved, the pig is committed.
Every man is the architect of his destiny.
Experience is the father of wisdom.
Faint heart never won fair lady.
Familiarity breeds contempt.
First impressions are the most lasting.
Good company on the road is the shortest cut.
Happiness will never come to those who don’t appreciate what they have.
Hatred is a blind as love.
He who laughs last, laughs longest.
Help the poor by not becoming poor.

How clearly does the behaviour of that unlearned heathen prove that shame is an artificial sentiment resulting from education alone; and that different communities measure propriety, nay even right and wrong, by various standards established under the operation of dissimilar circumstances.
I do not pretend that I have led a blameless life, or that one fault justifies another, but the public in judging a case like mine should remember that the darkest life may now have a bright side.
I have outlived that care that curries public favour or dreads the public frown…let the hand of law strike me down if it will, but I ask that my story be heard and considered.
I like villains because there’s something so attractive about a committed person — they have a plan, an ideology, no matter how twisted. They’re motivated.
I say to the young blokes, when you get asked for an autograph, don’t knock it back because there’ll be a time where no one will ask you.
I’ve never seen anyone rehabilitated by punishment.
If I had a donkey What Wouldn’t go, do you think I’d wallop him, oh dear no.

If my lips teach the public that men are made mad by bad treatment, and if the police are taught that they may exasperate to madness men they persecute and ill treat, my life will not be entirely thrown away.
If the guy next to you is swearing like a wharfie he’s probably a billionaire. Or, just conceivably, a wharfie.

If the section cannot remain here alive, it will remain here dead, but in any case it will remain here. Should any man through shell-shock or other cause attempt to surrender, he will remain here dead.
If you catch a man, throw him back!
If you go out for a big night and by some misadventure you end up in a prison cell, you can count on your best friend to bail you out, but your best mate will be in there besides you.
If you lie down with dogs, you’ll get up with fleas.
In particular, Australia, because of its ancient geography, soil profile and distinctive weather patterns, is more adversely affected by climate variability than some other continents.
Indeed I am not certain that every individual in the two English Houses of Parliament would be the worse for seven years, "lagging"; it would make practical men of them.
It is Australian innocence to love The naturally excessive and be proud Of a thoroughbred gelding who ran fast.
It is better to be defeated on principle than to win on lies.
It is easier to destroy than to build.
It is easy to remember your enemies, its easy to forget your friends
It is long accepted by the missionaries that morality is inversely proportional to the amount of clothing people wore.
It is the first step that is difficult.
It may be that your sole purpose in life is to serve as a warning to others.
It’s Australian to do such things because, however uncivilised they may seem, it’s human to do them.
It’s dead easy to die; it’s the keeping on living that’s hard.
It’s like the axe that’s had two new blades and three new handles but otherwise is just as it was when grandfather bought it.
It’s no good crying over spilt milk; all we can do is bail up another cow.
It’s rare that there’s a role that requires an Australian accent.
Leave tomorrow till tomorrow.
Lighting a cigarette with a sense of achievement for company made the journey worth it.
Lost time is never found again.
Many drops make a shower.
Nationalism is both a vital medicine and a dangerous drug.
Necessity is the mother of invention.
Never complain, never explain.

Not lip service, nor obsequious homage to superiors, nor servile observance of forms and customs… the Australian army is proof that individualism is the best and not the worst foundation upon which to build up collective discipline.
Nothing they design ever gets in the way of a work of art.
One gets tired of the role critics are supposed to have in this culture: It’s like being the piano player in a whorehouse; you don’t have any control over the action going on upstairs.
One good turn deserves another.
One man’s meat is another man’s poison.
Ordinary people need to lead and not sit there and think that governments are going to spoon feed them.
Out in the bush, the tarred road always ends just after the house of the local mayor.
Shoot straight you bastards. Don’t make a mess of it.
Some mistakes are too much fun to only make once.
Step by step one goes far.
Such is life.
Tears are words the heart can’t express.
The Australian accent is sort of like going down a step in smartness, you could say, because you guys pronounce things as they’re spelled. We add and abbreviate stuff.
The Australian economy is resilient, but business and consumer confidence is fragile.
The Australian fans are really friendly and personable; the sense of humour is a lot less dry than the English.
The Australian language is easier to learn than boat talk. It has a vocabulary of about six words.
The Australian nation is a nation of blow-ins and we’ve got the lot here – bog Irish, reffos, dagos, wogs, slopes, you name it.
The Australian people expect the Government to govern, they don’t expect it to make excuses.
The Australian people want to help build this country into a great nation. This budget has not realized the capacity of the Australian people. It has underestimated them. It has let us down.
The Australian public are very fair and they are always prepared to give a leader of a major political party a fair go.
The best way to help the poor is not to become one of them.
The bigger the hat, the smaller the property.
The cricket bat is mightier than the pen and the sword combined.
The difference between a stupid man and a wise one is the stupid man’s inability to calculate the consequences of the action. The same goes for government.
The family that prays together stays together.
The grass looks greener on the other side of the fence.
The hood does not make the monk.
The law locks up the man who steals the goose from the common, but leaves the greater criminal loose who steals the common from the goose.
The most intense hatreds are not between political parties but within them.
The only time an Australian ever walks is when his car runs out of petrol.
The pot calls the kettle black.
The sun shines on both sides of the hedge.

The true Aussie battler and his wife thrust doggedly onwards: starting again, failing again, implacably thrusting towards success. For success, even if it is only the success of knowing that one has tried to the utmost and never surrendered, is the target of every battler.

The twentieth century has been characterized by three developments of great political importance: the growth of democracy, the growth of corporate power, and the growth of corporate propaganda as a means of protecting corporate power against democracy.
The wowser mistakes the world for a penitentiary and themselves as the warden.
There are people who wish to draw attention to themselves by attacking me.
There is a thin line between love and hate.
There is nothing more Australian than spending time in somebody else’s country.
There is nothing so costly to the state as a ruined life.
There is something about the Australian psyche that seems to like films that are slightly offbeat.

They who came here in chains, who were lashed while they worked in convict gangs at Port Arthur. They who like many others were driven through starvation or oppression from their home-lands to the shores of this new country, Australia. They, who for a multitude of reasons that hopefully, I or my children will never witness or experience, decided not to harbour grudges or discontent but rather to look to the future. They who embraced this country as their own and said; "let’s get on with it, this is a new land, this is our home.
To each his own.
To plunder is at first as natural as to eat. How readily children lay their little hands upon every tempting article they see, until taught that it is not proper to do so.
Tomorrow is a new day.
True beauty lies within.
Unless you’re willing to have a go, fail miserably, and have another go, success won’t happen.
We are all visitors to this time, this place. We are just passing through. Our purpose here is to observe, to learn, to grow, to love; and then we return home.
We are all visitors to this time, this place. We are just passing through. Our purpose here is to observe, to learn, to grow, to love… and then we return home.
We are moving toward recognition of the first Australians in the Australian constitution.
We are not so much as disillusioned but illusion free.
We believe in the Australian promise; that if you work hard, you won’t be left behind.
We cultivated our land, but in a way different from the white man. We endeavoured to live with the land; they seemed to live off it. – Tom Dystra
We today take this first step by acknowledging the past and laying claim to a future that embraces all Australians.
We want to create a sort of linguistic Lourdes, where evil and misfortune are dispelled by a dip in the waters of euphemism.
What rugby league teaches you is that everything is temporary. The dead-set certainty is that there’s adversity coming as well as success. You may as well make the most of it while you can.
When you play test cricket, you don’t give the Englishmen an inch. Play it tough, all the way. Grind them into the dust.
Where there are Torres Strait Islanders there is a community.
Where there’s a will, there’s a way.
australian.description: This proverb is said to encourage people who want to give up. Sometimes, we face problems that seem impossible. But if you want it bad enough, nothing can stand in your way. That is what this proverb means—if you have the will to meet the problems that are in front of you, there is a way to overcome them.

australian.text: Whether the difficulty in disposing of criminals, and whether the production of so many denote an unsound condition in the mother country, must now be determined by the wiser heads now occupied with the subject. Nevertheless, one cannot help fancying that the necessity for cure, in a certain measure, be economically superseded by prevention.
While there is life there is hope.
Who needs a bodyguard, I’ve got a donk.
Why are people so unkind?
Winning needs no explanation, losing has no alibi.
Wisdom is better than strength.
You can’t live on bread alone.
A 1000 miles journey starts with a single step.

Being Aboriginal is not the color of your skin or how broad your nose is. It is a spiritual feeling, an identity you know in your heart. … It is a unique feeling that is difficult for non-Aboriginal to fully understand.
Hypocrite – mouth one way, belly ‘nother.

Land is a central part of the connection to country and to our identity as people. Many of our significant sites, landscapes, customs and stories focus on connection to land. Land is therefore very important to our culture, history and future.
May as well be here, we are as where we are.

The Aboriginal Sunrise Ceremonies are very special to our people. It starts when the sky is black, beautiful black. When the sun’s yellow circle arrives, it turns the sky red. This is why the Aboriginal flag is half red, half black with a yellow circle in the middle. At the Sunrise Ceremony, I meditate and ask the Great Spirit for direction. My hands fill with electricity. I touch you and you feel it, too. I heal people this way. My Grandmother did that, too. I learned all about that when I was a young fellow. Umbarra, the Black Duck, is the special totem of our tribe, the Yuin. We learn to respect the elders who hand on the Law. The elders guard the Law and the Law guards the people. This is the Law that comes from the mountain. The mountain teaches the dreaming.
The land owns us.
Traveler, there are no paths. Paths are made by walking.
You can’t judge a book by its cover.
australian.description: Things are not always what they seem. This proverb teaches you not to make judgments about other people because of how they look or dress. A book with a boring or plain cover could be amazing. The same is true with people. A person might look like an athlete or fool, but there is probably a lot more to them than clothes suggest.

australian.text: You can’t teach an old dog new tricks.
A bad worker blames his tools. Those who lose dreaming are lost.
Don’t count your chickens before they’re hatched.
australian.description: This proverb warns against being too eager. Just because you have five eggs, does not mean you will have five chickens. It is not a good idea to make plans based on expectations (what you think will happen). Wait for all things to come true before building up your dreams. Or worse, your promises. Things may not happen like you thought they would and that could get you in trouble.
